entry.title: Task Center ECC Connector ‚Äì Bridging the Gap During Your S/4HANA Transition
entry.content:
Are ECC-based workflows causing bottlenecks in your S/4HANA migration journey? You're not without a solution.

Introducing the ECC Connector for Task Center, delivered in partnership with MHP, a valuable enabler for customers navigating hybrid SAP landscapes. Whether you're mid-migration or working in a dual-system environment, this connector helps integrate your classic ECC tasks directly into the modern SAP Task Center experience on BTP.

What Is the ECC Connector?

The ECC Connector is a purpose-built solution designed to seamlessly pull tasks from ECC systems into SAP Task Center‚Äîyour central inbox for all workflow items across SAP and third-party systems.

Built on SAP BTP CAP architecture and deployed directly into your SAP and BTP infrastructure, the connector supports:

  • Pulling ECC-based approval tasks

  • Operating through My Inbox actions (including bulk operations)

  • Detailed task data including attachments and notifications

  • Backend extensibility for customer-specific enhancements

What‚Äôs Delivered as an ECC connector?

As part of the implementation, MHP provides:

  • BTP CAP API Interface deployed on your SAP BTP instance

  • Backend Interface in the MHP namespace for ECC/SAP on-premise systems

  • Full implementation support

  • Tailored adjustments to your business requirements

Scope & Eligibility

Your organization qualifies if:

  • You have a BTP subaccount with Task Center and Backend Connectivity enabled (via Cloud Connector & Principal Propagation)

  • You're running My Inbox on ECC for existing approval processes

  • Your SAP system meets minimum version: SAP_BASIS, SAP_ABA, SAP_GWFND ‚â• 750

Benefits and Roadmap

Current Capabilities Include:

  • Pulling tasks from ECC backend

  • Support for My Inbox actions (approve/reject)

  • Attachments, details, and multi-backend support

  • Easy display integration for My Inbox detail views

What's Next:

  • Adjustments based on early customer feedback

  • Enhanced support for multiple backend systems, clients, and 3rd party SaaS

  • Full SaaS readiness with 24/7 support, SAP Store listing, and standard rollout models

Why ECC Connector is crutial during S/4HANA Migration?

During your migration to S/4HANA, it's not uncommon to maintain hybrid landscapes where legacy ECC processes coexist with modern SAP BTP components. Instead of re-building workflows or forcing users into multiple inboxes, the ECC Connector provides a unified user experience, reduces disruption, and supports a smoother transition.

entry.title: Universal OData ‚Üî MCP Bridge; Or: How I Accidentally Made 15,000 Enterprise Services Talk to AI

Or: How I Accidentally Made 15,000 Enterprise Services Talk to AI

In March 2025 I realised the "hard part" of enterprise AI integration was already solved by metadata we've had for years. Two hundred MCP servers suddenly became 15,000+ ‚Äì with one simple translator. üöÄ

 

What Problem Are We Solving?

Hey folks! üëã This is the logical continuation of my ABAP-native AI journey:

  • ZVDB & ZLLM brought AI into ABAP (vector search, LangChain-lite, local inference)

  • This bridge brings ABAP ‚Äî and every other OData system ‚Äî to AI

Enterprises sit on thousands of OData endpoints that already expose clean business semantics, yet modern AI assistants can't reach them. All that was missing was a translator.

 

The "15,000+ MCP Servers" Moment

EcosystemOData services made AI-ready
SAP (ECC ‚Üí S/4 & BTP)‚âà 10,000
Microsoft Dynamics‚âà 1,500
Salesforce‚âà 800
Oracle Cloud ERP‚âà 2,000
SharePoint, ServiceNow & friends‚âà 1,000

Total: 15,000+ enterprise-grade services now surface as first-class MCP tools.¬π Not toys‚Äîsystems that move real money.

 

TL;DR (Four Bullets, Promise!)

  1. Code ‚Üí GitHub: oisee/odata_mcp (Python) & oisee/odata_mcp_go (Go) (link in first comment)

  2. Problem ‚Üí $2T of software speaks OData; 0% speaks MCP

  3. Solution ‚Üí Bridge auto-discovers every entity/action; zero config

  4. Result ‚Üí Your ERP landscape is AI-accessible in under two minutes

DeveloperOne interface for SAP, Dynamics, Oracle, Salesforce‚Äîwrite once, chat everywhere
Business user"Claude, approve all POs < $50k" ‚Äì and it just happens
 

The "Wait, That's It?" Moment

  • OData = REST + machine-readable metadata

  • MCP = JSON-RPC + tool definitions AI assistants understand

  • Bridge = translate the metadata to tool definitions. That's it.

‚û°Ô∏èJust translate between them‚Äîand you've unlocked the whole enterprise. ü§î

 PythonGo
Startup~3s~0.3s
Memory~150 MB~30 MB
Best forPrototyping & demosProduction workloads
Shared superpowersFull CRUD, function imports, CSRF juggling (hi SAP üëã), Basic auth, Cookies auth

Check the repo or catch me on SAP On Azure Podcast üéôÔ∏è

 

The Hidden Cost of Waiting

 Vendor AI (Joule / Copilot / Einstein)Bridge Today
AvailabilityCloud-only, phased rolloutAny OData v2/v3‚Äîeven ECC 2007
CoverageSingle vendorEntire landscape
Time-to-value6-18 months< 2 minutes
Data locationVendor cloudStays on-prem / your VPC
Vendor-LockHighZero (MIT licensed)
 

Security & Governance (Because Enterprise)

  • Runs inside your network ‚Äî nothing leaves unless you proxy it

  • Honours existing roles ‚Äî if users can't see it in GUI or Fiori - they can't see it via MCP

  • Audit trail-ready ‚Äî every request loggable with full context

No new attack surface‚Äîjust a protocol translator.

 

The Ecosystem Just Shifted

When 15,000+ production services become AI-accessible overnight, MCP stops being a dev toy and becomes the enterprise standard. This isn't iteration‚Äîit's inflection.

A Day in Your New AI-Powered Life

 

09:00  "Claude, what needs my attention?"
       ‚Üí 3 POs > $40k awaiting approval (SAP)
       ‚Üí Customer escalation (ServiceNow)
       ‚Üí Budget variance on cost center 4210 (Dynamics 365)
09:05  "Approve the POs from established vendors, escalate to Sarah, schedule variance review."
       ‚Üí Done. Next?

Five minutes. One assistant. Zero UI clicks.

 

What Could Go Wrong? (Let's Be Honest)

  • Query complexity: Some OData implementations choke on deeply nested $expands

  • Rate limits: Your backend might not love 100 requests/second from an enthusiastic AI

  • Schema changes: When your OData model changes, tools need regeneration

  • Governance: "Claude, show me all salaries" works if your auth is broken

But these are solvable with basic ops hygiene‚Äîrate limiters, caching, and proper RBAC.

 

Get Rolling in Two Minutes

  1. download pre-built binary for your platform: Release Universal OData ‚Üî MCP Bridge v1.0.0 (Multi-Platform Binaries) ¬∑ oisee/odata_mcp_go
  2. copy/rename to the appropriate folder (like C:/bin/ )
  3. update your claude_desktop_config.json correspondingly:

                "--service",
                "https://services.odata.org/V2/Northwind/Northwind.svc/",
                "--tool-shrink"
            ],
            "command": "C:/bin/odata-mcp.exe"
        }
    }

Add as many services as you want: just repeat with different --service argument

Instructions on how to build from source code - in README here: oisee/odata_mcp_go

But honestly? Even this changes everything.

Try It. Break It. Make It Better.

Here's what I need from you amazing people:

  2. Break it creatively - I love good bug reports

  3. Add your system's quirks - Every OData implementation is a special snowflake

  4. Share what you build - The crazier the use case, the better

Drop a PR, open an issue, or just share what happens when you connect your enterprise to AI.

Want This as an Azure Service?

Look, this open-source bridge proves the concept works. But I know what you're thinking - "Great Alice, but what about enterprise deployment, monitoring, compliance, support?"

Fair point. What if this was available as a managed Azure service? Zero setup, enterprise SLA, built-in monitoring, automatic scaling...

Drop a comment if you want that. üòâ

 

P.S. Yes, it handles all the authentication properly. Yes, it respects permissions. Yes, it works with your ancient SAP system from 2007. No, I don't know why this wasn't built years ago either. (Well, actually, I might know.)

entry.title: From ECC to Cloud: Your Essential SAP MM Guide for 2025 and Beyond
entry.content:
From ECC to Cloud: Your Essential SAP MM Guide for 2025 and Beyond

 

In the rapidly evolving world of SAP, staying current means embracing the transformative power of SAP Cloud. This blog brings you up to speed, explaining how the core principles of Materials Management (MM) have evolved within SAP's intelligent Business suite, highlighting the shift from traditional T-codes and tables to the user-centric Fiori experience and a simplified data model.

 

What is SAP MM (in the S/4HANA)?

 

SAP MM (Materials Management), now a core component within SAP S/4HANA, the next-generation intelligent ERP suite from SAP, continues to handle the critical functions of procurement, inventory management, material valuation, and vendor management. It ensures materials are available at the right quantity, at the right time, and at the right price, remaining the backbone of supply chain and logistics in enterprises.

While the fundamental business processes remain, SAP S/4HANA transforms how these processes are executed and how data is managed, driven by its in-memory HANA database and a simplified data model.

 

Why SAP MM in S/4HANA is Crucial for Business Operations

 

SAP MM in S/4HANA automates material flow, bridging the gap between departments and fostering real-time visibility and financial compliance. It streamlines:

  • Purchase requisitions and orders

  • Goods receipts and invoice verifications

  • Stock transfers and adjustments

  • Vendor evaluations and sourcing decisions

With deeper integration to SAP FI, CO, SD, and PP modules, and enhanced by intelligent technologies, SAP MM in S/4HANA empowers faster decision-making and more efficient operations.

 

Core Functionalities of SAP MM (with a Fiori Perspective)

 

The move to S/4HANA brings a strong emphasis on the Fiori experience. Here's how key MM functionalities are presented:

Feature

Description

Fiori Apps (Examples)

Purchasing

Manages Purchase Requisitions (PRs), Purchase Orders (POs), Requests for Quotations (RFQs), and Contracts.

"Manage Purchase Requisitions," "Manage Purchase Orders"

Inventory Mgmt.

Handles goods receipts, issues, and transfers, providing real-time stock visibility.

"Post Goods Receipt," "Stock - Single Material", Manage stock

Material Master

Central record for all materials, enriched with attributes for purchasing, inventory, and valuation.

"Manage Product Master Data" (classic T-codes like MM01/02/03 still available in some deployments)

Vendor Master

Maintains supplier information. Crucially, in S/4HANA, vendors are managed as Business Partners.

"Manage Supplier Master Data" (or T-code BP)

Invoice Verif.

Reconciles purchase orders, goods receipts, and vendor invoices.

"Manage Supplier Invoices," "Create Supplier Invoice - Advanced"

Material Valuation

Handles pricing and costing based on movement types, with a simplified data model.

Manage Material Valuations

 

Important SAP MM Tables (and their S/4HANA Evolution)

 

While many traditional tables still exist (often as compatibility views), SAP S/4HANA introduces significant simplifications and consolidations for improved performance and a "clean core."

 

Material Master Tables

 

These remain largely consistent, with underlying architecture optimized for HANA:

  • MARA: General material data

  • MAKT: Material descriptions

  • MARC: Plant-specific material data

  • MBEW: Material valuation

  • MVKE: Sales organization data (relevant for sales)

 

Vendor Master Tables (The Business Partner Revolution)

 

This is a major change in S/4HANA. All vendors (and customers) are now managed under the Business Partner (BP) concept. Traditional LFA1, LFB1, and LFM1 tables are still populated via Customer/Vendor Integration (CVI), but the BP is the leading object.

  • BUT000: Business Partner: General data I (The central BP table)

  • LFA1: General vendor data (linked to BP via CVI)

  • LFB1: Company code-specific vendor data (linked to BP via CVI)

  • LFM1: Purchasing organization-specific vendor data (linked to BP via CVI)

 

Purchasing Tables

 

These tables remain foundational:

  • EKKO: Purchase order header

  • EKPO: Purchase order item

  • EBAN: Purchase requisition

  • EKBE: History per purchasing document

  • EKKN: Account assignment in PO

 

Inventory Management Tables (The Rise of MATDOC)

 

The biggest simplification here is the MATDOC table, which consolidates data previously spread across MKPF (material document header) and MSEG (material document item). While MKPF and MSEG still exist for compatibility, MATDOC is the go-to for S/4HANA.

  • MATDOC: Material Document (Combined Header and Item) - This single table replaces MKPF and MSEG for new material documents.

  • MKPF: Document header for material movements (Still present, but data primarily accessed via MATDOC)

  • MSEG: Material document line items (Still present, but data primarily accessed via MATDOC)

 

Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

 

While not directly an MM table, the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) is a fundamental innovation. It consolidates financial postings from all modules, including MM (e.g., goods receipts, invoice verification), into a single table. This provides real-time financial insights and eliminates reconciliations.

 

Essential SAP MM Reports (and their Fiori Equivalents)

 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the emphasis is on SAP Fiori apps for a role-based, intuitive, and highly analytical user experience. While many classic T-codes might still be available in some S/4HANA on-premise or private cloud deployments, Fiori is the future.

Pro Tips for Using SAP MM in S/4HANA Efficiently

 

  • Embrace Fiori First: Fiori apps are your primary interface in cloud deployments. Get familiar with the Fiori Launchpad and its powerful analytical capabilities.

  • Leverage Embedded Analytics: S/4HANA's embedded analytics (often within Fiori apps) provide real-time dashboards and insights, reducing the need for separate reporting tools.

  • Utilize Dynamic Selections & Filters: Fiori apps offer extensive filtering options by document type, plant, material group, vendor, and more to refine your data.

  • Automate with Intelligent Technologies: Explore how S/4HANA leverages AI, Machine Learning, and Robotic Process Automation (RPA) within MM processes (e.g., automated invoice processing, predictive analytics for stock levels).

  • Understand Business Partner (BP): This is fundamental. All master data for vendors (and customers) is now managed through the BP.

  • Consider SAP Ariba Integration: For strategic sourcing and procure-to-pay, SAP Ariba integrates seamlessly with S/4HANA MM, offering enhanced collaboration with suppliers.

 

Cloud-Specific Considerations

 

If you're moving to the cloud, keep these in mind:

  • Extensibility: Direct table access (like SE16N) is often restricted in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Extensibility is achieved via Fiori apps, custom fields, and APIs, adhering to the "clean core" principle.

  • Upgrade Cycles: Be aware of the regular, mandatory upgrade cycles in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ensuring you stay up-to-date with the latest features.

  • API-Driven Integration: Focus on standard APIs for integrations with other systems, as direct database access is not the standard cloud approach.

 

Conclusion

 

Mastering SAP MM in the SAP S/4HANA era means more than just knowing tables and T-codes. It's about understanding the shift to a Fiori-first user experience, the simplified data model (especially with MATDOC and Business Partner), and the power of intelligent technologies.

By leveraging the right SAP Fiori apps, understanding the underlying data structure, and embracing the capabilities of SAP S/4HANA, you can significantly enhance your efficiency, streamline procurement and inventory processes, and drive smarter decision-making across your supply chain in 2025 and beyond.

Ready to take your SAP MM skills to the next level in the cloud era? Share your thoughts or questions in the comments below!

entry.title: I Built LangChain-lite for ABAP, and Solved the Enterprise AI Cold Start Problem
entry.content:
Why enterprise AI projects fail at the "last mile"

AGI has been achieved!* Now your ABAP-Native AI can reach enterprise data where it lives.

Hello! üëã It's Alice again, and I've spent the last 1.5 years building what I wish had existed when I started my AI journey: a complete LLM orchestration framework that lives entirely within SAP.

TL;DR:

  • GitHub: oisee/zllm (releasing incrementally - link in first comment)
  • Problem: Enterprise AI projects die in "integration hell" between proof-of-concept and production
  • Solution: Native ABAP AI orchestration - no Python, no APIs, no middleware
  • Result: Build production AI workflows in hours, not months

Remember my previous posts?

  • üîçZVDB brought vector search to ABAP

  • üìèPREDICTOKEN eliminated expensive tokenizer calls

  • üîóThe OData-MCP bridge connected 15,000+ enterprise services to AI

 

Those were puzzle pieces; ZLLM is the complete picture.

The "Last Mile" Problem Nobody Talks About

Your AI proof-of-concept is brilliant. The CEO is excited. Then someone asks:

"When can we connect this to our actual SAP system?"

Traditional Answer: "We need APIs, data pipelines, authentication, environments, deployments, monitoring..."

Six months later: Still in integration hell. üíÄ

ZLLM Answer: "It's already connected." ‚ú®

What Enterprise AI Actually Looks Like

This is what you can build today, in pure ABAP, with zero external dependencies:

" Complete customer intelligence pipeline
DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_extract_customer_data )    
  ( lo_analyze_behavior_patterns )
  ( lo_identify_upsell_opportunities )
  ( lo_generate_action_plan )     
  ( lo_update_crm_notes )         
) ).

DATA(lr_result) = lo_flow->exec( REF #( lv_customer_id ) ).

Time to production: Hours External systems involved: Zero** Integration code: Zero

The Template Engine That Understands Your Data

Here's where ZLLM gets magical - watch this:

" Your nested ABAP structure
DATA: BEGIN OF ls_order,
        customer TYPE BEGIN OF customer_struct,
          name TYPE string,
          vip_status TYPE abap_bool,
        END OF customer,
        items TYPE TABLE OF order_item,
      END OF ls_order.

" Template that just works
DATA(lo_pattern) = zcl_llm_00_pat=>new(
  'Customer {T-CUSTOMER-NAME} (VIP: {T-CUSTOMER-VIP_STATUS}) ' &&
  'ordered {T-ITEMS-PRODUCT_NAME} for ${T-ITEMS-PRICE}'
).

DATA(lv_prompt) = lo_pattern->apply( REF #( ls_order ) ).

The template engine automatically:

 

  • ‚úÖNavigates deep structure hierarchies
  • ‚úÖIterates over internal tables
  • ‚úÖConverts complex data to JSON when needed
  • ‚úÖHandles NULL values gracefully

 

No JSON glue code. No data mapping. No field-by-field extraction. It just works.

 

Lazy Execution: The Enterprise Performance Secret

Traditional AI workflows block everything:

# Traditional synchronous hell
result1 = llm.call(prompt1)          # Wait 3 seconds
result2 = llm.call(prompt2)          # Wait 3 seconds 
result3 = llm.call(prompt3)          # Wait 3 seconds
# Total: 9 seconds of blocking execution

ZLLM uses lazy execution for real performance:

" Start all operations immediately (non-blocking)
DATA(lo_result1) = lo_step1->start( ir_input ).
DATA(lo_result2) = lo_step2->start( ir_input ).
DATA(lo_result3) = lo_step3->start( ir_input ).

" Collect results when ready
DATA(lr_final1) = lo_result1->collect( ).  " ~3 seconds total

 

The Security Story Enterprise Can Actually Use

ZLLM includes security foundations that scale to enterprise requirements:

At Rest:

" Default: Symmetric XOR with seed (fine for PoC/development)
SET PARAMETER ID 'ZLLM_CODEC' FIELD '12345'.

" Production: Implement your codec interface
DATA(lo_enterprise_codec) = zcl_your_enterprise_codec=>new( ).

At Runtime:

" Inherits SAP's proven security model
" If user can't access data in GUI, they can't access via AI
" No new security surface area

Bottom Line: ZLLM starts secure enough for development and PoCs, with clear paths to enterprise-grade security when you need it.

Real Demo: 30-Second Customer Intelligence

METHOD generate_customer_intelligence.
  DATA(lo_extract) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Extract key purchasing patterns from: {T}'
    iv_sys = 'Return as structured JSON with trends'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).

  DATA(lo_opportunities) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(
    iv_usr = 'Based on patterns {T}, identify 3 upsell opportunities'
    io_llm = lo_llm
  ).

  DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
    ( lo_extract ) ( lo_opportunities )
  ) ).

  DATA(ls_customer) = get_customer_patterns( iv_customer ).
  RETURN lo_flow->exec( REF #( ls_customer ) ).
ENDMETHOD.

Result: SAP data ‚Üí AI analysis ‚Üí Business recommendations in 30 seconds.

Load Balancing: Right Model, Right Cost

" Smart routing based on complexity
DATA(lo_llm_smart) = zcl_llm_00_llm_lazy_composite=>new(
  io_llm       = lo_llm_mini     " Fast, cheap model
  io_llm_exp   = lo_llm_maxi     " Powerful, expensive model 
  iv_threshold = 1000            " Token threshold
).

" Simple queries ‚Üí Mini model (fast + cheap)
" Complex queries ‚Üí Maxi model (powerful + expensive)

 

 

PREDICTOKEN: The Secret Weapon

" Predict tokens before expensive API calls
DATA(lv_predicted_tokens) = zcl_llm_00_predictoken=>predict_tokens_gpt4( lv_text ).

IF lv_predicted_tokens < 500.
  lo_llm = lo_llm_mini.     " Cheap model
ELSEIF lv_predicted_tokens > 8000.
  lo_flow = lo_split_flow.  " Split into multiple calls
ENDIF.

Accuracy: 99.7% token prediction (R¬≤ > 0.997 on 50,000+ validation samples) without API calls.

One-Click Invoice Intelligence

Complete invoice processing workflow:

DATA(lo_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_extract_invoice_data )     
  ( lo_validate_against_po )      
  ( lo_flag_anomalies )          
  ( lo_generate_approval_routing )
  ( lo_update_workflow_system )  
) ).

" Process 1000 invoices in parallel
DATA(lo_parallel) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy_parallel=>new(
  io_step = lo_flow->to_step( )
  io_llm  = lo_llm
).

Getting Started: The 10-Minute Setup

 

  1. Run: ZLLM_00_ONBOARD - Configure your LLM endpoints
  2. Demo: ZLLM_00_FLOW_DEMO - See chaining in action
  3. Build: Your first workflow in pure ABAP

 

DATA(lo_llm) = zcl_llm=>new( 'DEFAULT.ENV' ).

Hello again! üëã It's Alice, and I have a confession: I absolutely love writing documentation.

But I hate writing it BY HAND. Especially in SAP's bizarre ITF format - that cryptic markup language designed back when the closest thing to modern markup was SGML, and HTML didn't even exist yet!

(Fun fact: ITF format was actually designed for SAPscript in the early 1980s as part of SAP R/2 - when "markup language" meant something completely different! ^_^)

But here's the thing - ZLLM has incredible documentation. Comprehensive, detailed, and perfectly formatted. And it lives exactly where every SAP developer NOT expects it: behind the standard "Show Documentation" button üòÉ

ZLLM documented itself.

The Documentation That Writes Itself

Click on any ZLLM class in SE80 or ADT. Hit CTRL+SHIFT+F2 (Show Documentation).

What you'll see isn't your typical sparse ABAP documentation. It's rich, detailed, with examples, architecture diagrams, and usage patterns. All perfectly formatted in SAP's native documentation system.

Here's what makes this magical:

The documentation exists in standard SAP format (ITF), appears in standard SAP locations, but was generated by modern AI and written in human-readable Markdown first.

How I Built The Documentation Factory

Step 1: The Analysis Phase

DATA(lo_analyzer) = zcl_llm_00_step_lazy=>new_from_string(

           '- Method documentation with examples'
           '- Code samples showing real usage'
           '- Integration notes and best practices'

  io_llm = lo_llm
).

" Chain it all together
DATA(lo_doc_flow) = zcl_llm_00_flow_lazy=>new( VALUE #(
  ( lo_analyzer )
  ( lo_generator )
) ).

" Generate docs for entire framework
DATA(lr_result) = lo_doc_flow->exec( REF #( class_metadata ) ).

For the Markdown ‚Üí ITF conversion and integration with SAP's documentation system, I used another one of my frameworks: XRAY. But that's a story for another article... ^_^

entry.title: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for India: Electronic Invoice in Utilities using Extensibility
entry.content:
You want to enable your system to create electronic documents for invoices posted in Utilities using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. In this blog, we‚Äôll show you an example on how this can be achieved using extensibilty.  

Prerequisite: 

Before you begin ensure that you have implemented the SAP Notes listed in 3569761 - Electronic Document Processing for India: Electronic Invoice using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition - Implementation Overview.‚ÄØYou can also refer the SAP Help Portal for more information, see Electronic Document Processing.‚ÄØ 

Steps to Create Electronic Documents

  • Append Structure Creation
    Create a 'Z' append structure to map utilities-specific fields to the source structure EDOC_IN_GEN_SOURCE. Include the following utilities-specific fields to the append structure.‚ÄØ
    Example: 

    Field Name 

    Component Type 

    Description 

    DOC_HEADER_ISU‚ÄØ 

    EDOC_ERDK‚ÄØ 

    eDocument: IS-U- Print Document/Header Data‚ÄØ 

    DOC_ITEM_ISU‚ÄØ 

    EDOC_ERDZ_TAB‚ÄØ 

    eDocument: IS-U Print Document - Item Data‚ÄØ 

    FKKVKP_ISU‚ÄØ 

    FKKVKP‚ÄØ 

    Contract Account Partner- Specific‚ÄØ 

    DFKKKO_ISU‚ÄØ 

    DFKKKO‚ÄØ 

    Header Data in Open Item Accounting Document‚ÄØ 

     
  • Implement FQEVENT R433 (Electronic Document Creation)
    Create a 'Z' function module to implement     FQEVENT R433, using the method PREPARE_EDOCUMENTS from the class CL_EDOC_SOURCE in FM. This method utilizes the factory class of eDocument IS-U to get an instance of the eDocument IS-U class. 
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION ZEDOC_ISU_IN_R433 .
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_BUPA) TYPE  EKUN_EXT
*"     REFERENCE(X_FKKVKP) TYPE  FKKVKP
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOC) TYPE  ISU21_PRINT_DOC
*"     REFERENCE(X_PRINTDOCNO) LIKE  ERDK-OPBEL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_UNIT) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT
*"     REFERENCE(X_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM
*"  TABLES
*"      T_VKK_DOC_ID TYPE  ISU21_T_VKK_DOC_ID
*"      T_BILL_DOC TYPE  ISU2A_T_BILL_DOC
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_land1       TYPE land1,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data,
        inv_doc        LIKE LINE OF t_vkk_doc_id,
        fkop           LIKE LINE OF inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_active,
         lv_msgtyp,
         lv_bukrs,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bapiret,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_t001,
         lt_edocument[],
         inv_doc,
         fkop.

  "Print Document Header
  ls_erdk = x_printdoc-erdk.

  READ TABLE t_vkk_doc_id INTO inv_doc WITH KEY id = 'A'.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    LOOP AT inv_doc-vkk_doc-t_fkkop INTO fkop
    WHERE NOT bukrs IS INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = fkop-bukrs.
      EXIT.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      SELECT SINGLE land1
        INTO lv_land1
        FROM t001
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0 AND lv_land1 EQ 'IN'.
        SELECT SINGLE active
          INTO lv_active
          FROM edocompanyactiv
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
            AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
        IF lv_active = 'X'.

          ls_fkkvkp = x_fkkvkp.

          TRY.
              ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
              MOVE-CORRESPONDING inv_doc-vkk_doc-fkkko TO ls_source_data-dfkkko.
              SELECT SINGLE *
                FROM t001
                INTO ls_t001
                WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
                ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
                ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
              ENDIF.
              ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
              ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
              ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
              ls_source_data-document_item = x_printdoc-t_erdz.
* Fill source document key
              cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                                                    IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

              GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
              lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

              IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

                lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                  iv_update_task = abap_true
                  iv_hook        = abap_true ).
                LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                  IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                    <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                  ENDIF.
                ENDLOOP.

              ENDIF.
            CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

              LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
                "Default type Error
                lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
                IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                  "eDocument has been created
                  IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                    lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                  ENDIF.
                ENDIF.
                MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                  WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                       ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
              ENDLOOP.

          ENDTRY.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Implement FQEVENT R428 (Reversal)
    Similarly, create a 'Z' function module to implement FQEVENT R428, using the same method as above for reversal process.
    Sample Code:  
FUNCTION zedoc_isu_in_r428. "#EC CI_FUNCTION
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_DOC OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_DOC) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_UNIT OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_REVERSAL_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_CANC_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_INVOICE_PARAM) TYPE  ISU21_INVOICE_PARAM OPTIONAL
*"     REFERENCE(X_CALL_ID) TYPE  C
*"  TABLES
*"      XYT_EITR TYPE  ISU21_T_EITR
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: lv_bukrs       TYPE bukrs,
        lv_active      TYPE edoc_active,
        lv_invopbel    TYPE opbel_kk,
        lv_msgtyp      TYPE symsgty,
        ls_erdk        TYPE erdk,
        ls_fkkvkp      TYPE fkkvkp,
        ls_bukrs       TYPE eitr,
        ls_t001        TYPE t001,
        ls_erdb        TYPE erdb,
        ls_dfkkko      TYPE dfkkko,
        ls_source_data TYPE edoc_src_data_isu_invoice,
        ls_bapiret     TYPE bapiret2,
        lt_erdz        TYPE edoc_erdz_tab,
        lt_t001z       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t001z,
        lt_edocument   TYPE edoc_instance_tab,
        lo_source_data TYPE REF TO cl_edoc_source,
        lo_edocument   TYPE REF TO cl_edocument,
        lx_error       TYPE REF TO cx_edocument,
        ld_source_data TYPE REF TO data.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <ls_edocument> TYPE edoc_instance.

  FREE: lo_source_data,
        lo_edocument.

  CLEAR: lv_bukrs,
         lv_active,
         lv_invopbel,
         lv_msgtyp,
         ls_erdk,
         ls_fkkvkp,
         ls_bukrs,
         ls_t001,
         ls_erdb,
         ls_dfkkko,
         ls_source_data,
         ls_bapiret,
         lt_erdz[],
         lt_t001z[],
         lt_edocument[].

* This event should be trigger only for reversal process
  IF x_call_id = 'R'.

    LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-t_eitr INTO ls_bukrs
    WHERE bukrs IS NOT INITIAL.
      lv_bukrs = ls_bukrs-bukrs.
    ENDLOOP.

    SELECT SINGLE *
      FROM t001
      INTO ls_t001
      WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
    IF ls_t001-land1 EQ 'IN'.

      SELECT SINGLE active
        INTO lv_active
        FROM edocompanyactiv
        WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs
          AND source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      IF lv_active = 'X' AND
      x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk-opbel IS NOT INITIAL.

        ls_erdk = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-erdk.
        lt_erdz = x_reversal_doc-new_print_doc-t_erdz.
        ls_fkkvkp =  x_reversal_doc-acc-fkkvkp.

        LOOP AT x_reversal_doc-old_print_doc-t_erdb INTO ls_erdb
        WHERE doc_id = 'A' OR doc_id = 'S'.
          lv_invopbel = ls_erdb-invopbel.
        ENDLOOP.

        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM dfkkko
          INTO ls_dfkkko
          WHERE opbel = lv_invopbel.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-dfkkko = ls_dfkkko.
        ENDIF.

        SELECT *
          FROM t001z
          INTO TABLE lt_t001z
          WHERE bukrs = lv_bukrs.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
          ls_source_data-t001z = lt_t001z.
        ENDIF.
        TRY.

* Source structure mapping
            ls_source_data-document_header = ls_erdk.
            ls_source_data-document_item = lt_erdz .
            ls_source_data-source_header-source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
            ls_source_data-source_header-bukrs = lv_bukrs.
            ls_source_data-source_header-land  = ls_t001-land1.
            ls_source_data-t001 = ls_t001.
            ls_source_data-fkkvkp = ls_fkkvkp.
* fill source document key
            cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>pack_key( EXPORTING iv_opbel = ls_erdk-opbel
                      IMPORTING ev_key   = ls_source_data-source_header-source_key ).

            GET REFERENCE OF ls_source_data INTO ld_source_data.
            lo_source_data = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>create_instance( ld_source_data ).

            IF lo_source_data IS BOUND.

              lt_edocument = lo_source_data->prepare_edocuments(
                                                                 iv_update_task = abap_true
                                                                 iv_hook = abap_true ).
              LOOP AT lt_edocument ASSIGNING <ls_edocument>.
                IF <ls_edocument>-edocument IS BOUND.
                  <ls_edocument>-edocument->create_edocument( ).
                ENDIF.
              ENDLOOP.

            ENDIF.
          CATCH cx_edocument INTO lx_error.

            LOOP AT lx_error->mt_message INTO ls_bapiret.
              "Default type Error
              lv_msgtyp = 'E'.
              IF lo_edocument IS BOUND.
                "eDocument has been created
                IF lo_edocument->mv_saved_in_db = abap_true.
                  lv_msgtyp = 'I'.
                ENDIF.
              ENDIF.
              MESSAGE ID ls_bapiret-id TYPE lv_msgtyp NUMBER ls_bapiret-number
                WITH ls_bapiret-message_v1 ls_bapiret-message_v2
                     ls_bapiret-message_v3 ls_bapiret-message_v4.
            ENDLOOP.

        ENDTRY.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.
  • Create Factory Class
    1. Create a 'Z' factory class to get the instance of eDocument IS-U class by inheriting CL_EDOC_FACTORY class and redefine its method CREATE_EDOC_INSTANCE. Example: ZCL_EDOC_FACTORY_IN_ISU
      Sample Code:  
  METHOD create_edoc_instances.

    DATA: lv_land_iso      TYPE edoc_land,
          lv_error_txt     TYPE string,
          ls_source_header TYPE edoc_src_header,
          lo_edocument     TYPE REF TO zcl_edocument_in_isu.

    CLEAR: lv_land_iso,
           lv_error_txt,
           ls_source_header,
           lo_edocument,
           et_edocument_obj.

* Country
    ls_source_header = io_source->get_header( ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'COUNTRY_CODE_SAP_TO_ISO'
      EXPORTING
        sap_code  = ls_source_header-land
      IMPORTING
        iso_code  = lv_land_iso
      EXCEPTIONS
        not_found = 1
        OTHERS    = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MESSAGE e881(b1) WITH ls_source_header-land INTO lv_error_txt.
    ENDIF.
    IF lv_land_iso <> 'IN'.
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    CREATE OBJECT lo_edocument 
      EXPORTING
        io_source_data = io_source
        iv_update_task = iv_update_task.

    APPEND lo_edocument TO et_edocument_obj.

  ENDMETHOD.

          2. Configure this 'Z' eDocument factory class in the view EDOFACTORYV using the transaction SM30.‚ÄØ

Source Type‚ÄØ 

Factory Class‚ÄØ 

ISU_INVOIC‚ÄØ 

‚ÄòZ‚Äô factory class name (your factory class that you just created)‚ÄØ 

  • Create eDocument Class
    1. Create a 'Z' eDocument class by inheriting CL_EDOCUMENT_IN_EINV class.  
    2. Add the CONSTRUCTOR method to your 'Z' eDocument class to map the 'Z' eDocument IS-U class name to ms_edocument-edocument_class.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
    3. Redefine the method DETERMINE_EDOC_TYPE to assign the eDocument type.
    4. Use the table TFK003EDOC to configure eDocument type against the accounting document type
      Example

    5.  Add the class CL_EDOC_PROCESS as 'Friends' of 'Z' eDocument class.‚ÄØ
      Sample Code:  
METHOD determine_edoc_type.

    DATA: lv_blart      TYPE blart,
          ls_tfk003edoc TYPE tfk003edoc.

    CLEAR: lv_blart,
           ls_tfk003edoc.

    IF mo_source->mv_source_type = cl_edoc_source_isu_invoice=>gc_src_isu_invoice.
      lv_blart = mo_source->get_blart( ).
*      ls_tfk003edoc = me->select_tfk003edoc( iv_land = ms_edocument-land iv_blart = lv_blart ).
      DATA: l_applk TYPE tfkfbs-applk.

      CLEAR: l_applk,
             ls_tfk003edoc.

      CALL FUNCTION 'FKK_GET_APPLICATION'
        IMPORTING
          e_applk          = l_applk
        EXCEPTIONS
          no_appl_selected = 1
          OTHERS           = 2.
      IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
        SELECT SINGLE *
          FROM tfk003edoc
          INTO ls_tfk003edoc
          WHERE land  = ms_edocument-land
            AND applk = l_applk
            AND blart = lv_blart.
      ENDIF.
      rv_edoc_type = ls_tfk003edoc-edoc_type.
    ELSE.
      rv_edoc_type = super->determine_edoc_type( ).
    ENDIF.
    ms_edocument-edoc_type = rv_edoc_type.

    determine_edoc_type_global(
      CHANGING
        cv_edoc_type = rv_edoc_type ).

  ENDMETHOD.
METHOD constructor.

  super->constructor( io_source_data                 = io_source_data
                      iv_edoc_guid                   = iv_edoc_guid

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Enabling Scalable Growth for Mid-Sized Companies

To succeed, they stay quick, dream up fresh ideas, chase growth and yet still juggle limited money, shifting customer demands and rules from many regulation authorities. That is where SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud steps in - a strong, public-cloud answer that scales on command, speeds up innovation, offers enterprise-grade tools and cuts out most of the usual IT headaches.

Scaling Smart: Navigating Growth Challenges in the Mid-Market Sector

Mid-sized companies find themselves compressed between the big companies and the start-ups. Like the big players, they do not enjoy huge IT teams or expensive resources for year-long tech rollouts, yet their day-to-day headaches are just as trapped. Running operations in multiple countries, adjusting several product lines, keeping up with shifting rules, and pushing ahead with digital change all demand solid tools and budget. After all these conflicts, keeping companies balance sheet in shiny condition is not that easy. If they hang on to that aging ERP or a patchwork of outdated apps and systems, the drag can swallow momentum, showing up as:

  • Extra stress in meeting tough compliance standards
  • Focus shift from priorities to non-priorities activities, hurdles that block entry into fresh markets or regions
  • Isolation that keep departments talking past each other
  • On-premises systems that pile up hidden total cost of ownership
  • Rigid procedures with little automation and avoiding changes which will keep away from latest and cost-effective solution.

 What is SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud product is all about?

With pre-configured best practices, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is a scalable, cloud-based ERP solution that optimises business operations. Through the Central Business Configuration tool, it facilitates industry-specific configurations, minimal customisation, and quick deployment.

Continuous innovation, real-time insights, and sustainability tracking are made possible by its integrated AI, machine learning, and tools such as Signavio and SAP Analytics Cloud. Flexibility and compatibility are guaranteed by a smooth integration with both SAP and non-SAP systems.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is a future-ready ERP platform that offers agility, innovation, and sustainability, making it the perfect choice for organisations looking to modernise. Below are the key features of SAP Public cloud,

Now, let‚Äôs see how all mentioned features can drive scalable growth for small and mid-sized companies.

Consider infrastructure upgrades, continuous system maintenance, specialised IT support, and those annoying manual updates. Traditional ERP systems can have some unforeseen costs. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, on the other hand, adopts a different strategy with its subscription-based model, allowing you to benefit from predictable operational expenses and a significantly reduced total cost of ownership (TCO).

Here are a few benefits:

  • You avoid the headache of project-based upgrades and receive constant innovations and updates.
  • No requirement for sizable IT staffs or substantial physical infrastructure
  • Backups, disaster recovery, and cybersecurity are all integrated into SAP's secure data centres.

Mid-sized businesses can now more easily access and afford enterprise-grade ERP capabilities thanks to this model. By using SAP public cloud, companies can save around 50% of implementation cost.

 

2. Accelerated ROI through faster deployment and adoption

Businesses can quickly and efficiently implement SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud thanks to the SAP Activate methodology and SAP ALM. Implementation time is greatly reduced, frequently going live in 12 to 16 weeks (For less complex business), thanks to predefined business processes, guided configuration tools, and automated testing.

This type of flexibility enables mid-sized businesses to:

  • Avoid long project cycles
  • Reduce the cost of implementation
  • Reallocate internal resources to strategic business objectives.
  • See a return on investment almost immediately. Additionally, SAP provides pre-configured industry content (such as for professional services, manufacturing, and wholesale distribution), which enables businesses to more quickly align with the demands of their particular sector.

I have seen often small and mid-size industries facing lot of challenges with resources and budget, SAP Public cloud solution can be real game changer for these companies. By using SAP public cloud companies can save around 60% of their time.

As per my experience, it will be always beneficial to business if they consider SAP cloud ERP as a package. It often includes ALM (Application lifecycle management), BTP (Business technology platform) and other services.

Advantages of the packages,

  • Pay as you go model
  • Cost effective
  • Bundled value
  • Quick time to value
  • Innovation Ready
  • For few products no separate licencing is required

4. Continuous Innovation, Delivered Quarterly

Thanks to automatic quarterly updates, SAP keeps your experience fresh and evolving bringing you new features, smarter tools, and meaningful enhancements like:

  • Keeping pace with changes in national laws and regulations
  • Refining processes and boosting overall performance
  • Enhancing intelligence and user experience through AI and machine learning

In todays competitive market business should focus on their priorities, it will be very dangerous for business to involved in unproductive or less productive area, especially it can be big hurdle for mid-size companies.

With Public cloud business can be competitive and flexible with enjoying access to newest product features available to them without any extra efforts on expansive upgrades and dip pre-launch testing. SAP will take care of all upgrade process on the behalf of companies so there will be very less chance of errors and failures.

5. Flexible, Future-Proof Scalability

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is thoughtfully built to grow with your business ‚Äî scaling effortlessly in every direction.

  • Companies can improve their systems by adding new functionalities as their needs evolve over a period of time, such as Integrated Order-to-Cash and Procure-to-Pay, Advanced Financial Planning & Analysis or subscription billing and real time data.
  • On other side once business expectation fulfilled they can use the same global template to expand into new business units, regions, or subsidiaries.

Since it‚Äôs built for the cloud from the ground up, businesses can easily scale without pouring money into new hardware. That makes it perfect for companies planning to grow internationally or handle mergers and acquisitions. Even mid-sized firms can tap into the public cloud to reach their goals faster and more affordably.

6. Built-in intelligent technology solutions

SAP S/4HANA Intelligent technologies that improve decision-making, simplify daily tasks, and optimise business processes abound in the public cloud:

Even with smaller teams, these features enable mid-sized businesses to function more effectively working smarter, not harder. To be more precise, business can also take advantages of Joule for reporting or taking accurate data from system is fraction of second.

Localisations for more than 40 countries are pre-installed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and include:

With all specific local features business can enter in the market with confidence as SAP has already taken all the headache and incorporated all region-specific issues in advanced in the SAP product, so business can concentrate on other important aspect which is important for business growth.

8. Collaborative Framework for Functional Integration

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud eliminates data silos and produces a unified picture of the company by integrating finance, supply chain, procurement, HR, and sales onto a single platform. Integrated analytics and dashboards provide decision-makers with real-time insights, such as:

  • Analysis of profitability by product, region, or customer

Better decision-making, faster reactions, and more strategic growth planning are made possible by this instant visibility.

Summary:  Impact on mid-size businesses

SAP S/4HANA is a game-changer for mid-sized businesses, acting as a powerful catalyst for growth and innovation that goes well beyond just being a cloud-based ERP. The goal of SAP cloud ERP is to transition all mid-sized businesses to the cloud, allowing them to experience significant improvements by leveraging all the features and technologies available for their growth.

In summary, considering all these points, we can confidently say that SAP cloud ERP is a key driver of success. It supports businesses in various ways, including strategy, value, cost management, innovation, and fostering genuine growth.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud isn‚Äôt just a tool for businesses aiming to expand without the usual headaches; it‚Äôs a true partner in growth. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud, customers can expect to see a 50% reduction in IT staff compared to traditional ERP systems.

entry.title: Include released successor objects from "cloudification repo" in your ABAP custom code migration
entry.content:
Many SAP customers are currently in the phase of migrating their SAP ERP systems to S/4HANA. For those who choose a brownfield or bluefield approach the old ERP system is converted and the customers extensions and own applications (Z* objects) become part of the new system.

Then, the process of Custom Code Adaptation kicks in where the ERP functionality is analyzed and corrected in a way that the objects run again in S/4HANA. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-the-abap-custom-code-migration-process/bc-p/14049622 or https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-system-conversion-custom-code-adaptation-process/ba-p/13337309 for more details.

The custom code correction process can be time consuming and challenging depending on the size and complexity of the original ERP system. A big part of the custom code objects will be touched. The basis for the checks and corrections is the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) with the check variant for S/4HANA (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023).

In case the customer wants to move functionality to SAP BTP ABAP or the S/4HANA (public) Cloud versions it is not sufficient to make the old ERP code just S/4HANA ready. The cloud versions have a heavily restricted set of the ABAP language (so called language version 5 ) and furthermore access to SAP standard objects is allowed to (relatively few) released objects only. For instance, you must not use the MARA table to read materials but the I_PRODUCT CDS. This information is stored in the so called cloudification repository (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-check-your-custom-code-for-abap-cloud/ba-p/13567124 ) which is regularly updated. (See https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc for the Raw data).

It contains as well successor information for some of the old ERP objects in particular for the data base tables which makes it particularly interesting for the custom code migration process. See note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3284711 for installation of the according ATC check / check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)"  in releases before 2023 FP 3.

The idea is now to use the officially released successors for the objects which need to be corrected anyway during the migration ERP -> S/4HANA.

A (simple) example: When accessing table SKA1 corrections could be necessary because of the new account type attributes e.g. GLACCOUNT_TYPE in S/4; secondary cost elements are saved now as well. This is found by the S4HANA_READINESS_2023. The same access is found by the "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" check as well:

The solution to solve both issues is to check if secondary cost elements are concerned and to follow the recommendation in the finding. In the correction the successor object (DDLS I_GLACCOUNTINCHARTOFACCOUNTS) should be used directly:

 

This combination approach makes a part of the own developments "cloud ready" and "S/4HANA ready" at the same time without a big additional effort. And anyway, it is better for upgrade stability to use officially released objects!

Here are 3 possible approaches to achieve this:

Approach 1: Out of the box: Combined Check

Create a Z ATC Check variant and select the checks from S4HANA_READINESS* and the check "Usage of Released APIs (Cloudification Repository)" . The easiest would be to copy S4HANA_READINESS* and then to select in the maintenance of the check variants (via transaction /nSCI):

 

 

Once you run the check you will see the result as in this example:

 

The findings from the combined check contain already all needed information but there are two shortcomings: the list contains many irrelevant entries; not all check categories (only when the successor is defined) nor all findings are relevant in the context of S/4HANA custom code adoption (e.g. Successor I_COUNTRY for T005 table doesn‚Äôt solve a Custom Code Migration issue).

Approach 2: Add information from Cloudification Repo manually

Instead of a combined check variant the successor information could be added via Excel / VLOOKUP (SVERWEIS in German) as well using these steps:

  1. Run the standard ATC check for Custom Code Analysis (e.g. S4HANA_READINESS_2023)
  2. Download the detailed list from ATC to Excel (include in any case the field reference object / Referenzobjekt)
  3. Download the cloudification repo from here https://github.com/SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc/blob/main/src/objectReleaseInfoLatest.csv
  4. Open the data in Excel and copy the sheet to your original excel in a new tab
  5. Add a new column to the first tab from ATC data and combine the data via VLOOKUP: find a possible successor objects in the released objects for the reference objects

A possible result could look like this:

 

I added an example excel for convenience reasons to Github here: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc/blob/main/ATC_S4HANA_CLOUDIF_REPO_EXAMPLE.xlsx 

Then, when processing the ATC findings, the successor objects from Excel can be used directly in the corrections.

Approach 3: Using a custom enhancement to the SAP ATC S/4HANA: Released objects as additional information

In order to avoid the manual Excel steps and to have a lean combined list of the relevant findings only there is also the possibility to enhance the "additional information" section via an implicit enhancement or via another copy of the standard check classes in the S/4HANA Custom Code area. If you decide for the enhancement you can use the methode GET_DETAIL_FROM_DATA_BUFFER  from the central utility class CL_CI_S4H_COMMON and add the successor object information there.

The result is that if there is the successor object available it will be put to the Additional Information Section of the findings as shows the following  example:

 

 

There is an example version on Github for this as well: https://github.com/Lutzi3/cloud_mig_atc 

Now the existing ATC S4HANA readiness check is enhanced by the new released object information such as that you can directly correct the old ERP object reference and replace it by the latest officially released SAP cloud ready object!

entry.title: Controlling, Scheduling, and Costing of Production Using Custom Fields in Routing Based on AVC
entry.content:
Business Requirement 

Company X wants to calculate the production cost based on the variant selected when placing an order for a product. 

Before Company X can quote a price to its customer, it would like to know the correct cost to achieve the right profit margin. The cost calculation should occur as soon as the order is received, and well before actual production begins.

Company X applies a multiplier to the standard cost of operations, which varies depending on the product's configuration. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP.

Solution at high level
This solution will focus on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and making it visible at the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole.
The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

Key Steps in the Solution

  1. Creating Custom Field
  2. Setting Up Configurable Material
  3. Integrating Workcenter Formula
  4. Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics
  5. Executing Business Processes

Creating Custom Fields

Company X uses a custom field, YY1_price_factor, within Production Routing. This field is set up using the Key User Extensibility's Custom Field App, under the Business Context: Manufacturing Bill of Operations Operation. The custom field is crucial for linking production routing operations to sales orders.

a. Choose Add Field in the Custom Fields app.The custom field YY1_price_factor is created for production routing operations.

b. Enable the business scenario Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for the custom field YY1_price_factor.

c. Optional: Enable the GUI in the User Interface tab if you wish to see the fields in the UI.

 

Setting Up Configurable Material

a. Set the configurable material as described. The configurable material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX is associated with class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX of class type 300. Characteristics such as AVC_CR_COUNTERWEIGHT_VXX or AVC_CR_FORKLIFT_VXX are used to execute sales order variant configurations.

b. Select the UsedfVarConfig checkbox.

 

Integrating Workcenter (WKC) Formula 

a. Map the custom field YY1_price_factor to the WKC formula parameter AZMDB1 in the Define Parameters activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

b. Create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZMDB1 to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

For more details, see Step-by-Step Guide to Setting Up Custom Fields in Work Center Formula Parameters.

For more details on Work Center Formula, see the blog Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter.

Setting Object Dependency and Characteristics

To utilize YY1_price_factor in object dependency, it is referenced to the characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX. This characteristic is calculated using a procedure in production routing, ensuring accurate cost calculations based on configuration changes.

a. Create characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX using the Manage Characteristics app.

b. Reference the characteristic to the PLPO table with the field name YY1_price_factor_PPO in the Addnl data tab.

c. Assign characteristic AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX to class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX using the  Manage Classes app.

d. Assign the class AVC_CL_COMMON_VXX to the configured material in Manage Product Master Data.

e. Create a global procedure with the characteristics AVC_CR_PRICEFACTOR_VXX in production routing.

f. Maintain dependency with type Procedure.

g. Enter the formula in the Dependency Editor.

Executing Business Processes

Sales Order Impact

When a sales order is created for CM-MLFL-KM-VXX, the calculated cost and profit margin are displayed. Changes in configuration, such as altering the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg, dynamically adjust the costing and profit margin.

a. Set the counterweight to 2,000 kg in Variant Configuration.

The profit margin is calculated for 2,000 kgs. 

This solution focuses on calculating the production cost based on the configuration and displaying it on the sales order. It doesn't deal with sales order processes as a whole. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_price_factor) in Production Routing.

b. Set the counterweight to 5,000 kgs in Variant Configuration.The profit margin is calculated for 5,000 kgs. 

Production Order Impact

In production orders, the custom field price_factor reflects changes in sales order configurations. For instance, changing the counterweight from 2,000 kg to 5,000 kg adjusts the price_factor from 2 to 5, demonstrating the direct impact of configuration changes on production costs.

a. Search for the material CM-MLFL-KM-VXX in the Manage Material Coverage app.

 

b. Choose Start MRP Run to create a planned order.

c. Convert the planned order to a production order. Once the production order is created, check the User Field price_factor in Operations. For counterweight 2,000 KG, the price_factor is 2.

d. Now, if this counterweight is changed in the sales order variant config to 5,000 KG, and the MRP run happens again to create the production order in the same way as described above. The price_factor changes to 5 as shown below.

By integrating custom fields and formulas, Company X provides a streamlined approach to managing production costs, enhancing visibility and accuracy in sales orders and production processes. This solution empowers businesses to make informed decisions and optimize their operations.

entry.title: Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter
entry.content:
Business Requirement

Company X wants to determine the duration or cost of operation required to produce a given product depending on factors like work center or tool.  

Company X uses a multiplier called the efficiency factor to the standard execution time, which varies depending on the age of the tools used or weather conditions, etc. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP. 

Solution at High Level 

This solution focuses on calculating the execution time of an operation based on the efficiency factor
defined during the creation/updation of production routing. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_EFF_FACTOR) in Production Routing.

Steps to follow:

1. Access the Custom Fields app from the SAP Fiori launchpad.

2. Choose Add Fields to create a custom field.

3. In the New Field popup, set the Business Context to Manufacturing: Bill of Operations  Operation (PP_BILLOFOPERATIONS_OPERATION)

4. Set the field type to Quantity with Unit, as no other Business context or field types are supported for Work Centre Formula Parameters.

5. Once the required data is entered, choose Create and Edit. 

6. On the ‚ÄØGeneral Information‚ÄØtab, take note of the‚ÄØField Component Name‚ÄØending with the suffix‚ÄØ‚Äò_PPO‚Äô. This suffix is used to map the custom field to a parameter. 

7. On the‚ÄØUser Interfaces‚ÄØtab, enable the custom field‚Äôs usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services. 

8. Enable the custom field‚Äôs usage for the relevant business scenario. Enable Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for Discrete Manufacturing.

9. Navigate back to Custom Field work list page.

10. Search for EFF_FACTOR. Select EFF_FACTOR for business context Manufacturing: Order Operation (PP_ORDER_OPERATION).

11. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field‚Äôs usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services.

12. Create a workcenter formula parameter ZPP in the Define Parameters activity (ID: 102242). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

13. Create the‚ÄØparameter‚ÄØwith‚ÄØorigin 8 (Custom Field from Operation). Fill in all the necessary data, leaving the‚ÄØ‚ÄòField Name‚Äô‚ÄØfield blank. 

14. Once the parameter is created, create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZPP to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity (ID: 102002). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

15. Once the parameter is created and formula defined, map the newly created custom field to Workcenter formula parameter. Use the Mapping Custom Tasklist Operation Fields to Work Center Formula Parameters configuration activity (ID: 106627) to map the fields. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

16. Therefore, the creation of the work center formula parameter, definition of the formula, and mapping of the work center parameter to the routing operation custom field are complete.
The next step will be to either create a new work center according to the business scenario or update the existing work center with the newly created work center formula.

17. In the work center, use the newly created work center formula parameter under capacities, scheduling, and costing as per the business need. 

Capacity:

Scheduling:

Costing:

18. For production routing, you can add new operations or update the same operation with a new work center having the newly created work center formula.

Change shown for routing operation 0060:

19. In the custom fields, EFF_FACTOR is visible, and we can enter some efficiency factor into it.

20. Create Production Order for same material.

21. Navigate to Operation Overview.

22. Note the set-up duration.

23. Come back to Routing and change EFF_FACTOR to 20.

24. Schedule the created PO for the same operation. You will notice a change in setup duration due to a change in EFF_FACTOR in the routing.

25. Similarly, in Production Order, change the EFF_FACTOR to 30.

26. Before rescheduling, note the set-up duration.

After reschedule, the duration changes based on the change in EFF_FACTOR.

By following these steps, Company X can effectively streamline its production processes, ensuring efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Embracing SAP Cloud ERP not only enhances operational accuracy but also empowers the company to adapt swiftly to changing conditions.

entry.title: Webcast Series: SAP's Four-Part Journey Through Architecting Modern SAP Landscapes
entry.content:
In an era where digital transformation has evolved from competitive advantage to survival imperative, enterprise architects find themselves at the crossroads of unprecedented technological convergence. The traditional boundaries between artificial intelligence, cloud platforms, and business applications are dissolving, creating both immense opportunities and complex architectural challenges. To address this shifting landscape, SAP‚Äôs global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory team recently delivered a four-part webcast series that charts a course through the most pressing architectural questions facing organizations today.

This series, "Enterprise Architecture for Modern SAP Landscapes," was developed at the invitation of the broader "Move to Cloud ERP" webcast series, powered by the SAP Global User Groups Organization to serve the worldwide SAP community."

It represents more than just technical guidance‚Äîit's a strategic roadmap for navigating the fundamental transformation of how businesses architect, deploy, and govern their technology ecosystems. From debunking persistent myths that paralyze decision-making to realizing the promise of clean core principles, each session builds upon the others to create a holistic view of modern enterprise architecture, delivering the practical insights that user groups across the globe have been requesting for their digital transformation journeys.

 

Part 1: Debunking Enterprise Architecture Myths

Date: June 10, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The series opens with perhaps the most critical challenge facing enterprise architects today: separating fact from fiction in SAP‚Äôs modern architecture paradigms. The opening session, ‚ÄúDebunking Enterprise Architecture Myths: Clean Core, SAP S/4HANA, and BTP,‚Äù tackles seven persistent misconceptions that continue to derail digital transformation initiatives across organizations.

These aren‚Äôt merely technical misunderstandings‚Äîthey‚Äôre strategic barriers that cost organizations millions in project delays and suboptimal architectural decisions. The session demonstrates how clean core principles extend far beyond SAP S/4HANA implementation, enabling strategic custom development while maintaining upgrade safety and innovation velocity. Through architectural patterns and real-world case studies, attendees learn to counter myths with evidence-based approaches that accelerate rather than impede transformation.

What makes this session particularly valuable is its focus on communication and stakeholder management. Enterprise architects often find themselves in the unenviable position of defending architectural decisions against deeply held misconceptions. This presentation equips them with the truths and techniques needed to lead evidence-based discussions in executive steering committees.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

Part 2: Architecting Innovation-Platform Ecosystems

Date: June 17, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The second installment shifts focus to one of the most significant architectural transformations of our time: the evolution from traditional product-platform ecosystems to dynamic innovation-platform ecosystems. ‚ÄúEnterprise Architecture for Transitioning from Product-platform to Innovation-platform Ecosystems‚Äù explores how enterprise architects can design the foundational layers necessary for fostering co-creation and external innovation.

This session is grounded in rigorous academic research by @Michael_Blaschke, drawing from his peer-reviewed studies on platform ecosystem dynamics and digital transformation patterns. The presentation unveils the architectural building blocks required to create open, scalable innovation-platform ecosystems that support API-first strategies and platform economics while maintaining essential governance and security controls.

The transition from product-platform to innovation-platform ecosystems represents a fundamental shift in how organizations create and capture value. Enterprise architects learn to design the organizational capabilities that enable ecosystem participation, support multi-sided marketplace dynamics, and unlock network effects‚Äîall while ensuring the organization doesn‚Äôt sacrifice operational stability for innovation velocity.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

Supporting Research:

  • Dynamic capabilities for transitioning from product platform ecosystem to innovation platform ecosystem
  • Capabilities for Digital Platform Survival: Insights from a Business-to-Business Digital Platform

 

Part 3: AI-First and Suite-First Convergence

Date: June 24, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The third session addresses perhaps the most complex architectural challenge of our time: orchestrating the convergence of AI-first capabilities with suite-first principles. ‚ÄúEnterprise Architecture Convergence: AI-First and Suite-First Strategy for Modern Digital Landscapes‚Äù explores how enterprise architects must evolve their frameworks to architect truly future-ready organizations.

This presentation goes beyond the typical AI integration discussion to examine the deeper architectural patterns required for pervasive AI adoption. The session demonstrates how to harmonize three critical elements: AI integration with Joule as the intelligent copilot, unified business data cloud capabilities for cross-portfolio insights, and consistent suite qualities that ensure security and performance at scale.

The convergence theme is particularly relevant as organizations struggle to integrate AI capabilities without fragmenting their existing architectural coherence. Dr. Blaschke provides practical guidance on designing landscapes that embrace AI-first thinking while maintaining the governance and integration integrity essential for enterprise-scale deployments.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

Part 4: Enterprise Architecture View on Clean Core

Date: July 1, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Principal Enterprise Architect, SAP

The series concludes with ‚ÄúRealizing Clean Core using Cloud Extensibility: An Enterprise Architecture Perspective,‚Äù which provides the practical implementation guidance necessary to transform architectural vision into operational reality. This session reveals how enterprise architects can maintain pristine core systems while enabling seamless cloud-based extensions.

The clean core principle represents one of SAP‚Äôs most significant architectural innovations, but its implementation requires careful balance between standardization and customization. The presentation demonstrates how to establish architectural guardrails that prevent core pollution, leverage cloud-native extension patterns, and create flexible composition layers that enable innovation without compromising stability.

This final session ties together themes from the entire series, showing how clean core principles enable the platform ecosystem transformations discussed earlier while providing the architectural foundation necessary for AI-first initiatives. The result is a comprehensive approach to enterprise architecture that balances the sometimes competing demands of standardization, innovation, and agility.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

The Global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory Impact

These sessions represent the expertise and experience of SAP‚Äôs global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory team, part of the Premium Engagement & Advisory practice. This specialized team serves as strategic business partners to regional enterprise architect teams, helping customers drive digital transformation initiatives across the globe. Their focus on board-mandated and critical customer situations positions them uniquely to understand and address the most complex architectural challenges facing modern organizations.

The team provides dedicated enterprise architecture expertise to enterprise-grade customers, partnering with senior executives to architect modern enterprises. This hands-on experience with strategic transformations informs every aspect of the webcast series, ensuring that the content reflects real-world implementation challenges and proven solution patterns.

 

Charting Your Architectural Journey

Together, these four sessions provide enterprise architects with a comprehensive framework for navigating the complexities of modern digital transformation. They address not just the technical aspects of architecture but the strategic, organizational, and governance challenges that determine transformation success.

The series acknowledges that modern enterprise architecture requires more than technical expertise‚Äîit demands the ability to lead organizational change, communicate complex technical concepts to business stakeholders, and design solutions that balance competing priorities across multiple stakeholder groups.

For the SAP Community's global audience of customers, partners, and practitioners, this webcast series offers both immediate practical value and strategic vision for the future of enterprise architecture. Whether you‚Äôre debunking myths in steering committee meetings, designing innovation-platform ecosystems, orchestrating AI-first transformations, or implementing clean core principles, these sessions provide the frameworks and insights necessary to succeed.

The journey toward modern enterprise architecture is neither simple nor straightforward, but with the right guidance and frameworks, organizations can navigate this transformation successfully. This webcast series represents a valuable resource for anyone committed to architecting modern enterprises.

Special thanks to Larissa Brinkmann and Krenar Kuqi for their excellent collaboration, and to the SAP Global User Groups Organization for providing this platform to showcase SAP‚Äôs thought leadership in enterprise architecture.

This series, "Enterprise Architecture for Modern SAP Landscapes," was developed at the invitation of the broader "Move to Cloud ERP" webcast series, powered by the SAP Global User Groups Organization to serve the worldwide SAP community."
